page.pageNote: Advertisements, columns 1 and 2; detailed account obtained from the special correspondence of the New York papers of the recent naval expedition in South Carolina, columns 3-5

div.head: Capt. Samuel F. Dupont
div.summary: Calls for the nation's gratitude to be directed to Captain Dupont, who commanded the naval expedition credited with capturing Port Royal and Beaufort, South Carolina.

div.head: Who Are the Traitors
div.excerpt: "That our Departments are infested with spies, has now become a palpable fact, and the interests of the cause demand a most searching investigation, to be followed up until the parties are discovered and hung."
div.summary: Expresses concern that there are spies within the government who have leaked information to the South about important military plans, as evidenced by the telegram from Jefferson Davis found at Port Royal.

page.pageNote: Article reporting the capture of the "would-be" ministers from the South to England and France, column 1; accounts of the arrest of Slidell and Mason, the men being sent by the Confederacy to England and France as ambassadors, column 2; news from western Virginia, columns 2 and 3; news from the South extracted from the Norfolk Day Book and the Charleston Courier, columns 4 and 5; advertisements, columns 4 and 5

div.head: Caution
div.summary: Warns citizens to lock their coops to protect the turkeys they plan to have at Thanksgiving from theft. Notes that thieves have broken into several coops already.

div.head: Their Whereabouts
div.summary: Reports that General Negley's Pennsylvania Brigade are encamped about 50 miles south of Louisville, Kentucky, where about twenty to thirty thousand troop are quartered.

div.head: Sad Occurrence
div.summary: Reports that on the way down the Ohio River to Kentucky, a man from General Negley's Pennsylvania Brigade from Allegheny City deliberately jumped overboard and drowned. Another man fell overboard on accident in a thick fog and was not recovered.

div.head: Pay of Deceased Soldiers
div.summary: Announces the Treasury Department's decision to provide the widows of dead soldiers with the pay the soldier had accrued. If there is no widow, the pay will go to the soldier's children, and if he was unmarried, his parents will receive the amount due him.

div.head: False Representation
div.summary: Relates the theft of $75 to $80 worth of silk by a young woman claiming to have been sent to Messrs. Hoke's Store by "a certain lady" to acquire the silk. It was later discovered that she was acting without the consent of that lady and that she had therefore stolen the material.

div.head: The New Regiment
div.summary: Corrects a previous story about General McAllen's regiment in the process of formation. Relates that General McAllen wants the regiment to be composed of the men of Franklin County and the surrounding areas and not to join companies already in existence at Harrisburg.

div.head: Marriages
div.summary: Mr. John Johnson and Miss Elizabeth Hart, both of Chambersburg, were married on November 19.

div.head: Marriages
div.summary: Mr. Caspar Mattes of Waynesboro and Miss Laura Lawrence of Washington County, Maryland, were married on November 7.

div.head: Marriages
div.summary: Mr. Samuel Bonebrake and Miss Kate Bocenstose, both of Guildford township, were married on November 10.

div.head: Marriages
div.summary: Mr. Jacob F. Strock and Miss Rachael Elizabeth Gelwicks, both from near St. Thomas, were married on November 13. Miss Gelwicks is the eldest daughter of Frederick Gelwicks.

div.head: Marriages
div.summary: Mr. Christian R. Ebersole, of Green township, and Miss Susan Rutt, of Hamilton township, were married on November 14.

div.head: Marriages
div.summary: Mr. Edward Fisher of Guildford township and Miss Martha E. Bemastaffer, of Quincy township, were married on November 14.

div.head: Deaths
div.summary: Alice Julia Culbertson, aged 18 months, died in Shanghai, China, on June 18, 1861. Her sister, Eliza Fitch Culbertson, aged 3 years, died there on August 8. They were the daughters of Reverend M. Simpson Culbertson and Mary D. Culbertson, missionaries of the Presbyterian Board of Foreign Missions at Shanghai.

page.pageNote: Description of the engagement at Port Royal taken from the Charleston Courier, column 2; brief sketch of the background of General Grant, column 2; advertisements, columns 3-5

Continuation of the account from page 1 of the naval expedition at South Carolina, including a proclamation to the people of South Carolina by General Sherman and a letter from flag officer S. F. Dupont to the Secretary of the Navy, columns 1 and 2; prices current, column 3; advertisements, columns 2-5
